extracted_concepts.definition: A roll of a d20 to determine the success or failure of an action, modified by an ability score and proficiency bonus, against a Difficulty Class (DC).

rule_logic.premise: Player character or NPC attempts an action with an uncertain outcome, and the Dungeon Master calls for an Ability Check
rule_logic.implication: Roll 1d20 + relevant ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient). Compare total to a Difficulty Class (DC). If total >= DC, the check succeeds; otherwise, it fails.
rule_logic.description_text: An ability check tests a character’s or monster’s innate talent and training in an effort to overcome a challenge. The DM calls for an ability check when a character or monster attempts an action (other than an attack or a saving throw) that has a chance of failure. When the outcome is uncertain, the dice determine the results. For every ability check, the DM decides which of the six ability scores is most relevant to the task at hand and the difficulty of the task, represented by a Difficulty Class. To make an ability check, roll one of the twenty-sided dice (d20) and add the relevant ability modifier. As with other d20 rolls, apply any bonuses or penalties, and compare the total to the DC. If the total equals or exceeds the DC, the ability check is a success — the creature overcomes the challenge at hand. Otherwise, it's a failure, which means the character or monster makes no progress toward the objective or makes progress at the cost of some consequence determined by the DM.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special form of ability check used when two or more participants' efforts are directly opposed, such as both trying to achieve the same goal or one preventing another.

rule_logic.premise: Two or more creatures' efforts are directly opposed (e.g., trying to do the same thing and only one can succeed, or one trying to prevent another's goal)
rule_logic.implication: Both participants make appropriate ability checks, apply bonuses/penalties, and compare their total check results. The participant with the higher total wins.
rule_logic.description_text: Sometimes one character's or monster's efforts are directly opposed to another's. This can occur when both of them are trying to do the same thing and only one can succeed, such as attempting to snatch up a magic ring that has fallen on the floor. This situation also applies when one of them is trying to prevent the other one from accomplishing a goal. In situations like these, the outcome is determined by a special form of ability check, called a contest. Both participants in a contest make ability checks appropriate to their efforts. They apply all appropriate bonuses and penalties, but instead of comparing the total to a DC, they compare the totals of their two checks. The participant with the higher check total wins the contest. That character or monster either succeeds at the action or prevents the other one from succeeding.

extracted_concepts.definition: The outcome when two or more participants in a contest achieve the same total on their ability checks.

rule_logic.premise: A contest results in a tie (participants have the same total check result)
rule_logic.implication: The situation remains the same as it was immediately before the contest was initiated.
rule_logic.description_text: If the contest results in a tie, the situation remains the same as it was before the contest. Thus, one contestant might win the contest by default. If two characters tie in a contest to snatch a ring off the floor, neither character grabs it. In a contest between a monster trying to open a door and an adventurer trying to keep the door closed, a tie means that the door remains shut.

rule_logic.description_text: Each ability covers a broad range of capabilities, including skills that a character or a monster can be proficient in. A skill represents a specific aspect of an ability score, and an individual's proficiency in a skill demonstrates a focus on that aspect. rule_logic.implication: If the individual is proficient in the *skill*, they apply their proficiency bonus to the unusual ability check, just as they would for the skill's normal ability check.

extracted_concepts.definition: A special type of ability check that does not involve rolling dice, representing an average outcome or a GM-determined secret success.

rule_logic.premise: GM wants to determine success without a die roll OR task is done repeatedly (e.g. searching)
rule_logic.implication: Calculate a 'passive score' instead of rolling. Base score is 10 + all normal modifiers for the check.
rule_logic.description_text: A passive check is a special kind of ability check that doesn't involve any die rolls. Such a check can represent the average result for a task done repeatedly, such as searching for secret doors over and over again, or can be used when the GM wants to secretly determine whether the characters succeed at something without rolling dice, such as noticing a hidden monster. Here's how to determine a character's total for a passive check: 10 + all modifiers that normally apply to the check. If the character has advantage on the check, add 5. For disadvantage, subtract 5. The game refers to a passive check total as a score.

extracted_concepts.definition: A mechanism allowing two or more characters to collaborate on a task, with one character taking the lead and potentially gaining advantage.

rule_logic.premise: Two or more characters attempt a task AND one character provides assistance to another
rule_logic.implication: The character leading the effort (or with the highest ability modifier) makes an ability check with Advantage.
exceptions: The helping character must be able to attempt the task alone (e.g., possess required proficiency).
The task must be one that is genuinely made more productive by multiple individuals.
rule_logic.description_text: Sometimes two or more characters team up to attempt a task. The character who's leading the effort-or the one with the highest ability modifier-can make an ability check with advantage, reflecting the help provided by the other characters. A character can only provide help if the task is one that he or she could attempt alone. Moreover, a character can help only when two or more individuals working together would actually be productive.

rule_logic.implication: Every individual in the group makes the required ability check. IF at least half the group succeeds THEN the whole group succeeds ELSE the group fails.
rule_logic.description_text: When a number of individuals are trying to accomplish something as a group, the GM might ask for a group ability check. To make a group ability check, everyone in the group makes the ability check. If at least half the group succeeds, the whole group succeeds. Otherwise, the group fails.
